Award.AwardTitle: CS 10K: The Utah Exploring Computer Science Initiative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Westminster College of Salt Lake City, in partnership with Brigham Young University, proposes to create a new one-semester course modeled on the LAUSD Exploring Computer Science curriculum. The vast majority of Utah high school students do not have the opportunity to learn about computing beyond a required computer literacy course. This project seeks to provide all students in Utah public schools with an alternative to this existing computer literacy course. The Utah Exploring Computer Science Initiative will adapt the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum into a half-year course that meets the computer literacy high school graduation requirement for the state of Utah. Over three years, the project will prepare and support 100 teachers with summer professional development workshops, monthly meetings held during the academic year, a mentoring program, and a supportive online community. The proposed project will better prepare students with more advanced 21st century computing skills and will increase student, parent and counselor awareness of computing. It is anticipated that the ECS course will improve student perception of computing as a discipline, leading to increased student interest in additional CS courses, which will in turn drive demand for more rigorous course offerings, such as AP CS A or the proposed, new AP Computer Principles course. The project goal is to have the majority of Utah students taking the ECS course to fulfill their computer literacy high school graduation requirement within 5 years.

Institution.Name: Westminster College of Salt Lake City

Performance_Institution.Name: Westminster College of Salt Lake City

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2012, like many states in the nation, Utah schools were not preparing students with the computational skills they needed to succeed in the 21st century. Recognizing that Utah students needed a computer science course to teach them to become creators of technolgy rather than simply users of technology, the Utah Exploring Computer Science (ECS) Initiative introduced the Exploring Computer Science course to meet a high school graduation requirement. The Utah ECS project was the first ECS project in the country to implement ECS statewide and the first to offer ECS as a half-year curriculum. Over the project’s lifetime, more than 200 Utah secondary educators were trained as ECS teachers, and the number of Utah teachers offering computer science courses quadrupled, growing from 38 to 164.

 

The Utah ECS Initiative is unique because it was the first to deploy ECS in a non-urban environment and to provide mentoring to new ECS teachers by pairing them with experienced ECS teachers from their district. The half-year ECS course proved to be successful, as it was widely embraced by Utah teachers and students alike. The Utah ECS Initiative includes teachers in 29 of the 41 Utah school districts, including the state’s 13 largest school districts. These 29 districts teach 85% of all Utah students enrolled in public schools. More than 10,000 students have taken ECS over the duration of the grant. And because the project targeted all large urban high schools early in the project, the racial diversity of ECS students was higher than those for the state as a whole; 68% white in ECS classes (vs 75% in Utah), 19% Hispanic (17%), 3% Asian (2%), 2% African American (1%), and 3% Native American (1%) in 2015-16. While only 37% of ECS students were female in 2015-2016, this percentage was more than double the female enrollment in all other computer science courses in Utah.

 

Analysis of ECS teacher surveys and student surveys found surprisingly few differences in CS teaching abilities between ECS teachers with prior CS background and ECS teachers new to CS.  By the end of their ECS course, even students with low prior confidence in their own CS abilities believed that anyone could succeed in CS, regardless of their teacher's CS background. All ECS students' interest in taking additional CS classes significantly increased after taking ECS. These results suggest that school districts seeking to provide computer science education for all their students can successfully staff their ECS classes by supporting existing secondary teachers with no prior CS background, provided this support includes quality CS professional development and mentoring.

 

Utah teachers and stakeholders were so enthusiastic in adopting the Exploring Computer Science course that the Utah ECS Initiative ultimately trained more than double the number of high school teachers originally targeted. The introduction of ECS has contributed to increased student interest in other high school computer programming courses, which enrolled 50% more students in 2015-16 than in 2012-13. Professional development for Exploring Computer Science teachers has shifted to Utah state agencies, supported by ongoing state funds, ensuring the sustainability of the Computer Science education in Utah high schools.

Modified by: Helen H Hu

    Utah Computer Science Teachers
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In 2012, like many states in the nation, Utah schools were not preparing students with the computational skills they needed to succeed in the 21st century. Recognizing that Utah students needed a computer science course to teach them to become creators of technolgy rather than simply users of technology, the Utah Exploring Computer Science (ECS) Initiative introduced the Exploring Computer Science course to meet a high school graduation requirement. The Utah ECS project was the first ECS project in the country to implement ECS statewide and the first to offer ECS as a half-year curriculum. Over the project?s lifetime, more than 200 Utah secondary educators were trained as ECS teachers, and the number of Utah teachers offering computer science courses quadrupled, growing from 38 to 164. The Utah ECS Initiative is unique because it was the first to deploy ECS in a non-urban environment and to provide mentoring to new ECS teachers by pairing them with experienced ECS teachers from their district. The half-year ECS course proved to be successful, as it was widely embraced by Utah teachers and students alike. The Utah ECS Initiative includes teachers in 29 of the 41 Utah school districts, including the state?s 13 largest school districts. These 29 districts teach 85% of all Utah students enrolled in public schools. More than 10,000 students have taken ECS over the duration of the grant. And because the project targeted all large urban high schools early in the project, the racial diversity of ECS students was higher than those for the state as a whole; 68% white in ECS classes (vs 75% in Utah), 19% Hispanic (17%), 3% Asian (2%), 2% African American (1%), and 3% Native American (1%) in 2015-16. While only 37% of ECS students were female in 2015-2016, this percentage was more than double the female enrollment in all other computer science courses in Utah. Analysis of ECS teacher surveys and student surveys found surprisingly few differences in CS teaching abilities between ECS teachers with prior CS background and ECS teachers new to CS. By the end of their ECS course, even students with low prior confidence in their own CS abilities believed that anyone could succeed in CS, regardless of their teacher's CS background. All ECS students' interest in taking additional CS classes significantly increased after taking ECS. These results suggest that school districts seeking to provide computer science education for all their students can successfully staff their ECS classes by supporting existing secondary teachers with no prior CS background, provided this support includes quality CS professional development and mentoring. Utah teachers and stakeholders were so enthusiastic in adopting the Exploring Computer Science course that the Utah ECS Initiative ultimately trained more than double the number of high school teachers originally targeted. The introduction of ECS has contributed to increased student interest in other high school computer programming courses, which enrolled 50% more students in 2015-16 than in 2012-13. Professional development for Exploring Computer Science teachers has shifted to Utah state agencies, supported by ongoing state funds, ensuring the sustainability of the Computer Science education in Utah high schools.
